Having lead the Nation in a New Era after the death of Borghese thanks to the approval of the Military Constitution, Vito Miceli has died today after a very long carreer, from NATO South European COntingencies, to the SID (The Italian Secret Services) and lastly as the Generalissimo of Italy. The Nation is not yet lost though, two generals have been selected by the Junta as possible successors. On one side Amos Spiazzi di Corte Regia, a former fellow of Generalissimo Miceli in the SID and who has had a key role in the Borghese Coup. Spiazzi is seen as the most likely successor, and unlike his rival, he actually benefits from a long political carreer on the monarchist camp, for which he still sympathizes to this day. On the other field Carlo Alberto dalla Chiesa, the most loved general in the country, seems to benefit from the approval of the population, who sees him as a moderate contender and a key to a stable society.

Having made no secret of his Monarchist sympathies, Generalissimo Amos Spiazzi has recently entered negotiations with the Savoy House, in particular with Victor Emmanuel, the son of late King Umberto II. Spiazzi and Victor have now been correspondants for a couple of years and the situation seems to have become favourable for the end of the exile imposed on the Royal House in 1948. The return of the Savoys will sign a final pacification with the monarchist side, who since the Referendum has been at odds with our government. Shall we go forward with the operations, the Savoys will take a state trip from their residence in Switzerland to Rome, where they will be greeted by the Generalissimo and taken to a tour of the Eternal City and later to a press conference.

Having long suffered from heart problems, Generalissimo Amos Spiazzi has left us today at the age of 78. The country mourns the leader and a state funeral attended by NATO leadership will take place tomorrow in the morning in Spiazzi's native city, Trieste.

At the late age of 87 years, Generalissimo Carlo Alberto dalla Chiesa has left us in his sleep earlier this night. Having made himself loved by the lower stratas of the population due to his efforts to fight organized crime and terrorism, dalla Chiesa's funeral is expected to be attended by thousands of people, many collaborators and even more survivors and families of people who have had their life threatened by the mafia. General dalla Chiesa surely will not be forgotten in the history text and his rule remembered as a stable period in Italian history.

To counter the continuous expansion of organized crime in the South of the Country, Generalissimo dalla Chiesa, who has in the past already served in Sicily in a similiar role, has organized a mass operation, nicknamed Operation Sicilian Vespers, to end this problem once and for all. 120.000 troops will be deployed to the regions of Sicily and Calabria, respectively operation zones of Cosa Nostra and 'Ndrangheta, and the civil administration of the regions will be subordinated to a military council, hopeflly this will resolve our problems.

Failing to pass a law regarding financing to private school, the current government has signed resignations, hoping to resolve the issues of the ruling Centre-Left majority through a new dialogue between the parties. The failure of the law clearly has only been the spark that triggered the powderkeg within the chambers. Indeed the Centre-Left has since its first government found much opposition from non-government parties, some even hoping for a possible coup, and the Right Wing of the DC headed by Antonio Segni has accepted the candidacy of Senate President Cesare Merzagora to propose an alternative to the current government. Grouping the DC and the PLI under a single bi-colour party, with outside support from PDIUM's Monarchists and PRI's Republicans, Merzagora, technically an independent, hopes to form a Centre-Right government to face the issues of our times and resolve a few constitutional issues. On the other hand the DC, PSDI, PSI, PRI coalition might not be as weak as expected and could and most likely will easily settle its issues and come forward with a new executive lead by Aldo Moro and oriented to the Left.

As the situation on our eastern border has stabilized following the London Memorandum and Trieste seems back in our fold, the legal status of Friuli-Venezia Giulia can finally be settled. Long home to autonomist sentiments, that sometimes have evolved into separatist parties, the politicial situation is finally ready to settle the question of Autonomy, extending to Friuli the same special status that characterizes Sicily and Trentino-Alto Adige. Although recognizing this autonomy would be greatly appreciated at home, this may anger the Yugoslavs who could see this as an insult to the Peace Treaties.

Today a celebration of the Victory of the Monarchy in the last Referendum organized by the National Democratic Liberal Concentration in Naples in Medina Street led to the killing of 9 people after clashes broke up due to the provocations of the counter-protestors. The counter-protest that had been organized by the PCI and the PSIUP was attacked by a group of young monarchists, leading the police to fire on the crowd. The nation is in shock and tensions don't seem to be dissipating, only God knows what this summer will reserve for Italy.

On the wave of the Medina Street Massacre tensions have been erupting throughout the whole country over the last few weeks, the PCI mobilized its activists over the killing of civilians during protests in Modena and Cosenza and in other cities the clash turned to day long barricade struggles. The city of Milan echoed the recent war following the attacks of Communist and Socialist militants who were protesting the removal of Communist Mayor and Partisan Ettore Troilo and news are coming that in Piedmont and Emilia-Romagna many veterans have been gathering on the mountains armed. To answer those attacks on the New Order right wing paramilitaries, often with dubious backgrounds, have begun to organize and counter back the social-communists. Our government is considering supporting the efforts of those brave men but the question of legality has been dividing our administration, the many argue for a total war on subversives but more cautious politicians would prefer just cover support.

After months of civil conflicts the situation has reached the point of no return. The PCI and its partisans have grouped with the PSIUP and their partisans to form alongside the Pd'A (Action Party) and the PRI a united front for labour, peace and republic. The catch-all front has taken up the name of Popular Democratic Front and has declared a rival Italian Republic in the 'red' regions of Tuscany, Emilia-Romagna and Umbria, with key control in the souther halves of Lombardy and Piedmont too. Palmiro Togliatti has quickly been elected Prime Minister of the new Republic while republican Carlo Sforza the new President. Now it's the time to take a last stand, shall we fight for Socialism and the Republic or shall we stand with the King?

As the war drags on our positions have been getting weaker and defections have not been rare, to endure those hardship an unconventional deal might be struck. Earlier during the war the Italian Movement of Social Unity, an organization grouping Fascist veterans, petitioned for the enrollment of former veterans in the National Struggle against Communism. Whereas we would gladly benefit from new and trained soldiers who are motivated to win this war, this decision could backfire on us, no one has yet forgotten the atrocities of the Mussolini Regime and many of those soldiers were until prior to the conflict detained for crimes during the war. The general population could not take well the decision of letting fascists once more roam free and we could see support for the communists rise.

Enterpreneur and President of the AC Napoli Team Achille Lauro has approached our government to offer his help in the war struggle. Coming from a family of dealers and having ammassed enormous wealth during the Fascist regime, Lauro is a convinced anti-Communist and one of the richest many in the country, his fleet is the biggest private commercial fleet in the whole of Italy. We gladly thank Mr. Lauro as the parliament discusses this proposition.

Following the victory of monarchists in the Italian Referendum of 1946 the country quickly plunged into chaos and then civil war, with the Communist Party taking leadership over the Republican faction. Shall the republicans win Italy may be very well lost to the Soviets and one more country would fall under Stalin's hands, we should do everything it's possible to help the King win.

As red troops entered the Eternal City papal diplomacy quickly mobilized their ways to move the Pope out of Italy. Pius XII, a longtime anti-Communist, is suspected to be on the hitlist of many partisans and the papal conclave is afraid that his capture could mean the end of the temporal power of the Catholic Church. Pius has left for Naples disguised as a taxi driver and there he will leave first for France and then from there gather international recognition to his cause. The catholics of the whole world pray for the salvation of the Pope and his Church.

Calm has been restored and so has the Pope. Following the re-conquest of the city of Rome by our brave soldiers and its pacification our government has been mediating the return of the Pope to his seat in the Church of St. Peter. Thousand of catholics have gathered in front of the Vatican hailing the restored Pope and mourning the deaths of the war. The King himself with his family was one of the many attendees of the luxurious celebration. Among those the most prominent are Spain's Generalissimo Francisco Franco, irish Taoiseach Eamon de Valera and brazilian President Getulio Vargas. Shall the Church last a thousand more years.

The Red Threat has been defeated, King and Nation have triumphed, freedom has triumphed. The republican authorities have surrendered and although minor battles are still going on we can safely say that it's over. Togliatti and Nenni have run to Moscow and the Constituent Assembly has begun to restart peacetime activities. A bright and democratic future awaits Italy among the western nations. The King will soon address the Nation and marches are scheduled for the evening.

Right after the Victory in the Second Italian Civil War the Constituent Assembly has begun the work on the first constitution of the Kingdom as agreed during the War of Liberation. Since 1848 the Savoyard domains have been subject to the Albertine Statue, a constitutional statue that worked as country's constitution through various emendments, but during the partisan struggle an agreement was made between former king Victor Emmanuel III and the political leaders of the Resistance, establishing the Constituent Assembly that managed the 1946 Referendum, after the Referendum the second task of the assemblyw as to draft a new constitution in line with the current century. After months of work the job has finally be completed and the liberal-democratic forces of our government worked perfectly to propose a progressive constitution that respects the history and the values of Italy. Now it just needs the King's approval and it will enter in effects.

Having succeeded his father Victor Emmanuel III in 1946 amidsts political instability and violence Umberto II did not receive any formal coronation event. Now that peace has been restored and Victor Emmanuel III is sadly dead the time to arrange a lavish ceremony for the King has finally come. The King has been greeted by the Monarchs of all of Europe, from Britain's George VI to Juliana of the Netherlands, Gustaf V of Sweden, Leopold III of Belgium, Frederick IX of Denmark and Iceland, Haakon VII of Norway, Paul of Greece and even Monaco's Rainier III. Many former monarchs like Michael of Romania, Zog of Albania and little Simeon II of Bulgaria have attended and even Farouk left Egypt to visit Rome. Alongside the monarchs many Head of States have attended. Although the event has been called the start of the Rebirth of Italy, for many detractors of the monarchy the expenditures by the governments have been exagerrated and could actually hurt the reconstruction of the country.

Since having helped us win the War Achille Lauro has quickly rised through the ranks, becoming Mayor of Naples and shaping the culture and landscape of the city. Lauro has become a symbol of the South that stood in the name of the King and Tradition, under his leadership the City has seen a cultural revival, rediscovering her customs and becoming a regional intellectual capital, with many movies being produced there and the citizenry being very active in the institutions. We all thank Lauro and the people of Naples also thank Lauro.

Since ENI has been established, its chairman Enrico Mattei has quickly been pushing his own agenda and using any mean possible to achieve his goals. Not only has ENI expanded to own its own armed forces, but to conclude his deal with the Shahansha he has proposed to King Umberto II to marry off his daughter Maria Gabriella to the Emperor of Persia. This deal is very important, shall Mattei manage to close it Italy would be the first nation to deal oil in Persia outside of the Anglo-American Conglomerate that has been suffocating the nation, this deal could also favor an alliance with the millenary state of Persia and begun our process of an independent foreign policy. On the other hand the King does not so keen on selling off his daughter like she was cattle and family relations could get sour over this.

The Millenary Empire of Persia has crumbled to socialists and islamists alike after months of civil strife. Revolutionary forces have quickly seized the government and taken control of many embassies and oil fields, putting at risk our own investments. Escaping this tragedy the Shah of Persia Reza Pahlavi has sought political asylum in our country, being tied to our royal family and a longtime ally. The Shah has already been denied asylum by the United States and fears that many western nations could do the same, dooming him to face the angry revolutionaries, hosting an exiled leader could boost our position in international diplomacy and also pay back the debt owed to the Pahlavis, on the other hand we might anger the new regime and its allies, disturbing our oil policy in the middle east.

Tensions between king Umberto II and crownprince Victor Emmanuel have been a costant since his teenage, when the king had to have the army supervise him, but now they have reached a boiling point. It has emerged that in January 1970 prince Victor Emmanuel and his fiance Marina Doria have married through civilian rite in Las Vegas. Umberto has never liked Marina Doria, for she was the daughter of an industrialist with no noble blood and for her skiing carreer. The prince now wants a religious marriage to be arranged and confirm the former, but according to the laws of the House of Savoy any dynatic marriage needs the approval of the head of the House, Umberto, who has already been denouncing the marriage. This is a very bad day for the Savoys and their reputation, prince Victor Emmanuel has been ruining the face of the Monarchy in the eyes of the public and Umberto doesn't seem to want anything to do with this. Shall he proceed with the marriage without an approval of the King-Father he shall be excluded alongside his future kids from succession, but shall the two come to terms Umberto could secure himself a linear succession.

Having served his country and people all his life, king Umberto II has died in his sleep. The death of the king marks the end of an era, as the leader who lead Italy out of fascism and into the democratic west he will not be forgotten, but with his death we see also the emergence of a new generation, younger and less attached to the past. Now we can only mourn and see what the future awaits.

As Victor Emmanuel was excluded from succession, since the death of Umberto II Amedeo of Savoy-Aosta has been proclaimed king, and now it's finally the time for his coronation. Amedeo is the son of Aimone, also known as Tomislav II during his brief rule of Croatia, the poster boy of fascist propaganda, and is going to be the first leader of Italy to not come from the main branch of the House of Savoy but from its cadet branch of Aosta. Although having a troubling familiar past Amedeo has long been one of the main spokespersons of the former King, having represented Italy and Umberto at many international conferences and to many countries. Having a past in the navy Amedeo has always been close to the West and we expect a calm and peaceful decades to come.

Having reconciliated with his father Victor Emmanuel will soon be crowned king of Italy as Victor Emmanuel IV. Since the marriage with Marina Doria was recognized by Umberto relations between the two begun to get better and now the young king can claim to be his undisputed successor. Prosperous decades await our Nation and Victor Emmanuel IV will lead us through those with the best of his skills.

Our time has come, the forces of the Popular Democratic Front that fight for freedom, democracy, peace and labour have come together Now it's the time to carry on the tasks of the War of National Liberation, mobilizing workers, peasants and all partisans alike, it's a crucial struggle for the future of our country and the leaders of the republican movement have finally proclaimed the Italian Provisional Republic. In these very ours not only are the lower stratas of the population being organized but the nationalization of controlled industries and the redistribution of land has already begun. The Garibaldi Brigades, the Justice and Freedom Brigades, the Matteotti Brigades, the Mazzini Brigades and smaller autonomous fighting formations have been liquidated and merged into a single Popular Republican Army. Now it's the time for change, down with fascism, down with the King!

After the outrageous results of the 1946 Referendum on the Monarchy in Italy, our comrades in the PCI have had little to do but to resort to armed struggle. The progressive forces of the italian peninsula have rallied behind the banner of the Republic and are waging a war of liberation. With the costant threat of Anglo-American reaction and intervention it might be in our interests to funnel funds and materials to the italian resistance, securing a good ally in the mediterranean.

The King and his fascist collaborateurs have been defeated, the vast majority of the country is under our control. The escape of King Umberto II to Portugal has widely been considered an official surrender and the current cabinet is relocating to Rome to set up the new Republic. General Secretary and Prime Minister Palmiro Togliatti has gathered alongside other major leaders in Rome to proclaim the triumph of democracy and anti-fascism to the masses. The people are celebrating everywhere and this is truly a great time for Italy, finally the nation has freed itself from all oppressors and can lead herself into the future.

Marshall Tito has recently approached our government to offer his help. Collaboration between Italian and Yugoslav partisans dates back to World War II and for quite some time the Communist Brigades located in Friuli directly received orders from the Slovenian section of the Communist Party of Yugoslavia. Marshall Tito proposes that belgrade could funnel a substantial ammount of economic and military aid in exchange for the abandonment of Gorizia. If we accept the deal, our troops in the North East would quietly help the takeover of the region by the Yugoslavs, while Tito and his troops would also march on Triest, breaking the agreed occupation zones. This is a very riskious move that has split the ruling government, republicans and socialists are deeply opposed to the secession of any italian territory while the communists strongly favour this decision, which has also been pushed by Moscow. It is true that in this very period we need all the help we can gather but for many this could be a humiliation and we also risk the intervention from the United States in Triest.

As Italy is being ravaged by a civil war and our relations with the PCI have soured due to the situation in Moscow, a group of generals in Belgrade has drafted a plan for an intervention in the conflict. Friuli has long been inhabitated by a cospicuous slovenian minority and while we failed to reach our brethren in the region during World War II, we may come in their help in this very moment. A few battalions would be dispatched to seize Gorz, while a stronger bulk of the army would march on Triest, breaking the internationally agreed occupation zones and escalating tensions with the west.

As part of a greater battle plan Yugoslav Communist Forces have entered Triest breaking the internationally agreed occupation zones and frontiers. The Government of Tito claims to have taken the mantle of regional administrator of the Triest Free Territory but we all know that they only plan on annexing those lands for their own good. We have seen hundred of thousand of italians flee Yugoslavia in the last couple of years and we can't imagine how worse the situation could get shall they get Triest and Gorizia. On the other hand a military intervention could be very costly and unpopular, weakening our position in this emerging world order, it is now in the hand of the President to decide the fate of the italians of Istria.

The succession of Amedeo to the throne has not been welcomed by Victor Emmanuel, the son of Umberto, who has gathered a number of supporters and 'legittimists' who believe it is his right to be the new king. Having gathered outside of the Basilica of Superga, the century old family church of the Savoys, he has been giving speeches in condemnation of Amedeo and in support of his own claim, going on tirades about the past of the House of Savoy and the greatness of its legacy. We don't know the echo those words will have and how many supporters does Victor Emmanuel have, but this is surely a serious inconvenience for the new king.

Victor Emmanuel has recently been found guilty of participating in an illicit worldwide gun trade. The former prince, who has already been stripped of his royal titles after his Superga speech where he proclaimed himself King of Italy during the coronation of the actual king Amedeo, has been discovered to be involved in a worldwide gun trafficking scandal that may or not may not include people such as the Shah of Persia and different middle eastern top officials. Victor Emmanuel worked as a dealer for the sold of guns in countries subjected to embargoes and it seems that he had also been enmassing some on his own to prepare a possible coup. The former prince is facing the maximum sentence in Italy for his crimes but the question of territoriality has arisen, he could be extradited to France, as the fictious firm he used to make his shady business is registered there, where he would face an even harsher sentence, shall italian courts extradite him.

At the age of 78 king Amedeo has left us after a heart failure. Amedeo was the first of his family to rule over Italy. The Savoy-Aosta, who have their roots in Amedeo I of Spain, the minor brother of king Umberto I of Italy who had been elected King of Spain by grace of the parliament, have long been known for their eccentricity, Emanuele Filiberto, grandfather of the deceased Amedeo, was one of the most important generals of the First World War and later an avid supporter of Mussolini while his two sons Amedeo and Aimone were known for their heroism and charm with women. Despite this familiar past Amedeo was instead a serious king and a moderate that was able to manage the dynastical succession in the best of the ways, despite the resistance of his cousin Victor Emmanuel. Amedeo was a big enjoyer of cinema and had a gardening hobby, having even opened his own wine brand. His son Aimone, who is set to succeed him will be opening the funeral ceremony, where guests from all of Europe will be coming to mourn the later king.

After Amedeo died his son Aimone acted as King and now it's the time for his formal coronation. Aimone who was born in 1967 has up until the death of his father been an active diplomat for the italian monarchy worldwide and a succesful businessman, he managed the Savoy Royal Estates, including his father's winery and has been living between Turin and Moscow for the last 30 years. Indeed Aimone has been a diplomat to Moscow, helping the spread of italian business to the lands east of the Dniepr. Now he is expected to be an eccellent ruler and the crowning ceremony will be attended by most monarchs of Europe, but not only, in a surprising turn of events the heirs of the last king of the Two Sicilies will also be taking part in the celebrations, marking an important moment of reconciliation in italian history.

Peace has returned but now the battle is being fought in parliament. The Pd'A (Action Party) has unilaterally withdrawn from the Popular Democratic Front citing disagreements with the front's leadership and disapproval of PCI's intimidatory tactics as causes of the split. The 'Azionisti' as the members of the Pd'A are called, were the last remnants of italian pre-WWII liberal tradition, a group of liberal socialists as they called themselves, who have been active in the resistance since the Leggi Fascistissime. This is the first sign of weakness between the coalition of democratic forces since 1922. The withdrawal of moderate and liberal elements from the front signify the growing predominance of the Communist Party over its ranks and many believe this is the prelude of one party rule, but only time can tell.

Today is a big day, the first free elections since 1922 are going to be held. The voters are going to be presented with mainly two lists, the Popular Democratic Front, headed by Palmiro Togliatti's PCI, the PSIUP, the PRI the PCS (Christian Socialist Party) and many other smaller left wing organizations who have became relevant during the War of National Liberation and the subsequent Civil War, and the opposition, which is not an actual united list but more of an informal agreement between the Pd'A and other parties in disagreement with the ruling coalition to form a government that can stop the Social-Communists. The ballots are ready and whoever is going to win these elections will leave a big mark on Italian History and finally open a new chapter.

Six prominent figures of the resistance have recently been called to answer the charges of treason. Giuseppe Saragat, Ludovico d'Aragona, Ugo Guido Mondolfo, Angelica Balabanoff, Giuseppe Emanuele Modigliani and Paolo Treves, who, except for the first two, have all jewish roots. These intellectuals and partisans who have been involved in the fight against fascism since 1922 have been accused of being western spies, zionists, trotskysts, turatists and counter-revolutionaires plotting to re-store the King and break the efforts by our government to collectivize the land and the factories. This trial comes after months of frictions between the ruling Popular Democratic Front and the adoption of the Zhdanovshchina by all Communist Parties worldwide. These six men and women were indeed brought to court thanks to the combined action of the NKVD and our agents. Whatever the outcome of this trial shall be this is a turn of tides in the history of the young Italian Republic, signifying a downwrds trend towards the loss of civil and political freedoms.

As social-communist control of the country is firm, the new and first italian constitution is finally ready to be promulgated. The legal body that has been informally dubbed the "Togliatti Constitution" will abolish the provisional status of the republic and turn it into a people's democracy by the name of Italian People's Republic, under the guidance of the front. The constitution sets the objectives of socialism, world peace and cooperation as primary goals of the italian state and outlines various measures to secure the rights of all citizens and in particular in the workplace. For the first time in our history the charter also safeguards the rights of women and their partecipation in the political and economic life of the country, making it an obstensively progressive document.

After the resignation of the first communist prime minister Umberto Terracini the President needs now to assign the role to a new man who can form a solid majority in government, the first choice having won the election is of course the social-communist coalition. The PCI itself has asked for a new mandate lead by Togliatti himself and demanding a more strictly communist cabinet which would centralize most power in the hands of communists and prune out the prior independent ministers, but maintaining the positions of the PRI and the PSI from the old cabinet. Some elements of the DC have been trying to convince President Einaudi on the other hand to form a moderate government that could get the outside support of the PSI to stop the communist rise and rally the opposition behind the figure of father Dossetti, a prominent figure within all catholics and very close to the instances of the PSI.

The Togliatti government has quickly been able to anger various factions of the army and the police force tied to the USA and NATO. Prior to the 1948 elections the OSS managed to funnel hundred of guns to the DC and the Police to defend themselves in the possibility of Communist victory, well the victory came and so the guns are now being used. Carabinieri and Police are currently seizing key government facilities in the biggest cities of the whole peninsula while the army brigades that are taking part in the coup move in the countryside. General Secretary and Prime Minister Togliatti is asking the people to take up arms and resist this assault on democracy while the corps still loyal to the government and partisans try to re-install government control in the occupied facilities. This is now a fight between democracy and western reaction, we shall see who will come out on top.

Thanks to the support shown by the italian people and our brave partymen democracy and anti-fascism have triumphed, fighting back the elements of reaction. To avoid any similiar incident in the future the parliament has drafted some key constitutional amendments that would be able to avoid the repetition of these events and secure the social-communist government. The amendments have informally been nicknamed the "Togliatti Constitution", it seems indeed that the FDP's proposed changes go far beyond the scope of fixes and propose instead what seems like a brand new document, very akin to the one seen on the other side of the Iron Curtain, with the outlining of the goal of socialism and world peace and the cementification of front rule. Now those changes are up in a referendum that shall be by itself a referendum on the work of the social-communist government, many already lament the set-up of the referendum to be unfree, with partisan troops involved in the ballots.

As President Einaudi refused to accept the resignation of Terracini, protests and strikes organized by the PCI have popped up throughout the whole peninsula, destabilizing the country and its economy. It seems that now there is little to do but to accept those resignations and form a new government, but the question is, what govenrment shall follow? Three possibilities arise, Togliatti personally has been seeking a government lead by him and including the PSI, that would exclude the former FDP allies and bring the country closer to his own hands, but there is also the possibility that such a government may not find trust in the parliament and his plans for domination will be ostracized by an uneasy coalition with moderate republican forces such as the PRI the Christian Socialists and the sardinian autonomists of the PSd'Az. A braver proposal has also arisen, Antonio Segni has been designated by the opposition as the man that could save the country from communism leading a full DC government with the outside support of most of the parliament to implement special laws and stop communist infiltration.

State power has finally come back under our control but now we need to end the social-communist threat once and for all. The debate has mostly been moving around whetever to make only examples of the FDP leaders for inciting rebellion and treason or if to go all out with a red scare firing any card carrying member from government job and providing public lists of frontist sympathizers that could have their carreer ruined. This is a very important choice for the stability of the republic.

General Secretary Togliatti has recently received an offer from Stalin himself to be the Chairman of the Cominform, the Information Bureau of the Communist and Workers' Parties. This is a very important role that would on the other hand take up a lot of time from his role as leader of Italy. In the eventuality that Togliatti shall accept this position has head of the european communist movement a General Secretary-in-pectore shall be picked to substitute him in his absence. This figure has been identified in Pietro Secchia, a hardline communistn who has been right handman of Togliatti since the resistance and an excellent partisan leader, he will act as head of government of the Republic until Togliatti's term as Cominform Chairman come to an end.

The Party has recently come under humiliation by the defection to the West of Giulio "Nino" Seniga, the personal secretary of Pietro Secchia. Seniga while defecting brought with him a staircase full of reserved documents regarding our intelligence and party apparatus. This has brought under suspicion the whole clique that revolved around Secchia and Secchia himself, who the party in an extraordinaty session will vote on whetever to expell or not, alongside his followers. No one could have seen this coming from such a vivid supporter of the revolution and the general trust around the hardline bolshevik has been dropping seriously after having long been thought the most likely successor of Togliatti.

Following the XXth Congress of the CPSU in Moscow the echoes of the "secret speech" against Stalin and his crimes have reached Italy, setting the party on chaos. General Secretary Palmiro Togliatti, one of the closest friends of Stalin while he was alive and trusted follower of his doctrines, has called on a congress to quell the spirits and address the situation. Having been close to Khrushchev during his rise, Togliatti is expected to follow the line and start a wave of de-stalinization, renaming streets, squares and removing statues, but we may never know if he will backtrack on the last events and re-confirm his longtime friendship with Stalin despite pressures from Moscow, it is true that during the last couple of years of the man of steel, his relations with the italian leader had begun to deteriorate and tensions to arise, especially regarding the future of the communist movement.

Similiar to what happened in Moscow with their "Anti-Party Group" opposing any attempt at de-stalinization, a local version of the hardliner clique has formed, also taking the name of "Anti-Party Group", spearheaded by Pietro Secchia, the former right hand of Togliatti and resistance leader. This group started during the current party meeting a surprise vote on the chairmanship of Togliatti, to be passed on to Secchia. Togliatti has been accused of fallimentary leadership in the political and economic field, with his agrarian reform vividly under fire, he has also been discredited by the group for the condemnation of Stalin and his legacy. The coupplotters don't have a majority in the Central Committee and the success of this operation lays in the hand of the army, that filled with former partisans, has remained close to Secchia the whole time. We shall see how this develop.

In a surpising turn of events the leadership of the PSIUP has decided to break with the PCI over the events in Hungary. Nenni and his clique within the PSIUP have voiced harsh protests over the soviet intervention in the Hungarian Revolution and have quickly decided to bring their party out of the Popular Democratic Front. To the unilater decision of Nenni a minority faction headed by Lelio Basso has decided to split from the PSIUP as the PSI (Italian Socialist Party) and re-enter the Front. Our government is now considering to disband the front and re-organize it as the Anti-Fascist Front for Peace, Socialism and Democracy, expanding the mass organization and changing its rank-and-file. The question of the PSIUP has instead been less easy, with factions calling for the total liquidation through a ban of the PSIUP in favour of the PSI and those prefering to force our hands into a reconciliation between the two socialist parties pruning the most vocal opponents.

As outlined in the Bucharest Conference of Representatives of Communist and Workers Parties of last June, now it is time to host in Moscow an International Meeting to address the divergences between the CPSU and the CCP. Our Party is participating with a delegation lead by Togliatti and it is rumored that he will try to talk Khrushchev into pacification with Mao. General Secretary Togliatti has been very concerned with the latest developments between the two biggest socialist nations and has taken the matter into his own hands theorizing a theory of polycentrism, where a united communist bloc would be characterized by its multipolarity and collective decision making. Whetever Togliatti will voice his theories at the soviet and chinese delegations we don't know, but this might eb a start for a detente in a period of such ideological heat.

As a part of the International Meeting of Communist and Workers Parties, General Secretary of the PCI Palmiro Togliatti has come to Moscow representing his country and party. Recently after the scheduled meeting he has reached out for the General Secretary to discuss the Sino-Soviet Split. Togliatti made a strong case for the de-escalation of sino-soviet relations, citing the fracturing of hegemonic communism as a big loss for the workers of all countries. Togliatti has brought forward what he dubs the theory of polycentrism, consisting in the establishment of a brotherly socialist bloc that must stand united despite its internal differences through an international body with no prevailing power over it, this of course undermines our hegemony over the communist movement, but it is true that we might try to act in a less paternalistic way towards Mao and the CCP, developing instead a policy of mutual cooperation in spite of minor ideological differences, if we are to hear the Italian leader we should instantly call a new meeting with the chinese and try to find a middle ground.

The Soviet Union has shrugged off General Secretary Togliatti's cry for unity and thus we are left in a precarious situation. How shall we act from now on? Shall we just give it up and give it in to Moscow or should we put our chances into Mao and the CCP? There is also the possibility of taking distances from both sides and maintaining a balanced foreign policy that would also allow us to restart dialogue with Tito and his people, who could come in handy after their re-approachment with the soviets to mediate a neutral position similiar to that of Ho Chi Minh.

During the capture of Rome the Pope and Cardinald flew to France to escape capture or repercussion by communist forces. Now that he has been in exile for a couple of years the effects are starting to show. Our popularity with the catholics is always very low and in some regions of the south the Church is actively acting against our government. It has appeared that to deal with the issue of the Pope and his follower we may need a Bureau for Religious Affairs, that could manage the already existing Christian Movement for Peace and the Organization of Anti-Fascist Priests, two front organizations for catholics and priests alike, but that most of all can mediate our relations with the Holy See in exile and particularly with the weakest links of the Conclave. To entertain in secret relations with the Holy See means to be able to get a better ground for the return of the Pope to the Vatican and the partecipation of catholics in the Republic.

The new Pope John XXIII has, in a historic choice, decided to return to Italy. John XXIII, born Angelo Giuseppe Roncalli was elected shortly after the death Pius XII, the hardcore anti-Communist that fled during the civil war. Pope Roncalli has always been a moderate and a reformist and his election by the conclave in exile instantly opened the way for a reconciliation between our two factions. Our diplomats and spies caught the chance and instantly started secret talks with the Holy See for a safe return for the Pope to Rome. Now John XXIII is hailed in Rome by believers that have gatehred in front of the Church of St. Peter right before the scheduled meeting with the General Secretary.

Pope Pius XII has recently died and a conclave has been called to elect a new Pope. Pius XII had till his death opposed the establishment of the Italian People's Republic and declared himself a prisoner in the Vatican. Despite this opposition we managed in the last few years to build connections with a few cardinals that may turn useful in this very moment. Given the position of our government we could use our connections and our pressure from the city of Rome to push a friendly candidate to the papacy. Our interference if rightly managed could gain us more support from the catholics, but shall our involvement be discovered the backlash could be huge.

Pope Leo XIV has been elected by the papal conclave at its 7th meeting. Leo was the man indicated by our secret services to be most fit for the job and his election signifies a great success for our covert operations. Pope Leo is expeced to show more leniency to the regime and to overwrite some of the most limitative encyclicas of Pius XII. While the election of this "red" pope has been welcomed by italians and the communist authorities, abroad he does not seem to be engaging in such popularity, with american catholics voicing serious concerns about the papacy.

Insider news from the conclave indicate that voting patterns are not going to favour our candidate. It is debated that the situation may need our intervention. We could force our hands paying off a few cardinals and making threats on others to swing the elections, but we will first need to be able to snuggle our agents into the very closed conclave, which is by itself a very riskious operation. Some unorthodox party members are also suggesting that if the situation keeps going against us we may have to militarily intervene in the conclave, dissolving it and shocking the whole world. We have very little time for decisions and we must be careful in considering the pros and the cons.

General Secretary Palmiro Togliatti died of stroke at the age of 71 earlier this night at the Policlinico Gemelli hospital in Rome where he had been staying for the past few days. The death of Togliatti has shook the nation, with his wise leadership he lead the country out of the war and into a new prosperous era and even got the nickname of "il Migliore", the best, for his merits. Having become General Secretary in 1938, he has lead the PCI in its fiercest battles and now the people cry his death. Togliatti wasn't only a well liked figure at home but also internationally, he was a functionary of the Communist International and a personal friend of Stalin. Leaders from all the Eastern Bloc have reached Rome to mourn the death of the late General Secretary, with some also prolonging their stay to assist the PCI party congress that will be taking place after the funeral.

The XIth Congress of the PCI has opened and it is the first since the foundation of the party to not have Togliatti in its committee. Now the various party factions are fending themselves off over the leadership of the country. After the death of Togliatti Luigi Longo, a charismatic moderate very close to the chairman, took over functions as acting party leader following the known procedures. It is very likely that Longo may be confirmed chairman at the congress as his position is the closest to the one of Togliatti and he is a man that could very well mediate the dissent between the other two factions, the supporters of Amendola and those of Ingrao. Giorgio Amendola is one of the most prominent figures of the resistance active in Latium and he represents the reformist wing of the party, aiming at a more "frontist" policy and a hint at detente. Amendola is also very tied to the Legacoop and his election may bring very much power to this planning body. On the opposing faction we have Pietro Ingrao, another man from Latium who positions himself as a leftist, favoring a heterodox marxist position that tries to bring the workers closer to political and state power.

The XIth Congress of the PCI has opened and it is the first since the foundation of the party to not have Togliatti in its committee. The fight for the leadership of Italy seems to have narrowed down to two people, Leonilde "Nilde" Iotti and Luigi Longo. Longo has been the acting general secretary since the death of Togliatti and he is seen as a moderate man within the party, a true successor to Togliatti's politics. Nilde Iotti instead is the second wife of the deceased leader, having met during the partisan struggle they only managed to actually marry under the People's Republic. The position of Nilde Iotti is a peculiar one, politically she is not far from Longo but on the diplomatic side, where she excels, she has been very close to the CCP and Mao following the split among the Communist Bloc and it is clear she will bring Italy into the Chinese fold.

The XIth Congress of the PCI has opened and it is the first since the foundation of the party to not have Togliatti in its committee. The fight for the leadership of Italy seems to have narrowed down to two people, Leonilde "Nilde" Iotti and Pietro Secchia. Nilde Iotti, the second wife of the deceased chairman, is set to bring forward the polyedric policies of her husband, but not without her own touch, she has been a long proponent of an independent foreign policy within the Communist Bloc and at home she is expected to tow a line between a conservative and reformist stance. Although Iotti seems to be the most likely candidate to succeed Togliatti, the former vice-secretary Pietro Secchia could pose a threat to her election. Secchia has been the most hardcore voice within the PCI since the partisan struggle and his line has often been described as anti-Revisionist and bolshevik.

Togliatti has been stuck in Bucharest due to Cominform work for more than a year now, it is the prime opportunity to cement our rule in the country. If we want to keep ruling the country even in the eventual return of Togliatti, we must act now with a purge, but to what extent? Some argue for the demotion and expulsion of key followers of the former leader while other want to go after all sympathizers in italian society, so to prevent any possible powerbase for the restoration of Togliatti.

The latest developments within the Communist and non-Communist World and the sudden shift of goals towards Europe from Asia have made the role of the Cominform superflous. It has been agreed that that the change in world politics calls for the dissolution of the Information Bureau and the formation of a new kind of organization better at dealing with global developments. The Cominform is outdated and never was able to address the crisis it faced properly, it is time to go away with this remnant of stalinist policies.

Following the dissolution of the Cominform Togliatti has decided to return home and is soon expected to land at the Fiumicino Airport in Rome. Togliatti expects a warm welcome, full of felicitations and to be soon hailed back as General Secretary, but the reality might be colder. While he surely will receive all the honours of the return his prospectives of power will have to be ridimensioned. It is very unlikely he will be restored but under the example of Moscow we will most likely procede with a collective leadership, where General Secretary Secchia will continue his job as Prime Minister and Chairman while Togliatti will get the honour of being President of the Republic.

The uneasy collective leadership has come to an end as Togliatti has moved his supporters in the Plenum of the Central Committee of the PCI against General Secretary Secchia. It seems that Togliatti and his supporters might have the numbers to overthrow Secchia all at once but Secchia's ties to the military might work against the attempted coup. If it were to come to that the bolshevik hardliner could fend off the strike against his leadership through the interruption of the plenum by the army. The situation is very tense, we shall see its developments.

The Collectivized Agricultural System inherited from the Togliatti leadership has proved itself very failing and lead to different shortages. The situation has also been aggravated by the growing bureaucratism of the Legacoop and its control over the collective farms. We have two solutions to this issue, either we start a grand scale mechanization project to empower the local farms and increase their output, we could also try to force our hand on Legacoop and alter the buying prices to allow for greater autonomy for the collective farms that would allow for the purchase of more modern farming tools to be bought independently, or we can give up on self-sufficiency in the field and start importing grain from the USSR itself.

Nearly 15 years have happened since the Communists tried to seize power unconstitutionally and the support for our junta seems to have decreased by the years. It may be fair to believe that the juntan outlived its purpose and that democracy could be restored, even though a longer stay into power could only do us good.

An avid internationalist and revolutionary General Secretary Secchia has brought forward to the party the motion for a worldwide tour in the developing world to stronger ties with the local independence and socialist movements and expand our influence abroad. This project will necessitate the expenditure of some of the state budget in international travels and aid, but we will not be the only ones who will benefit from this, we will be making a favour to the whole world furthering the cause of independence and solidarity at the expenses of our state budget.

General Secretary Secchia has finally reached the first stop of his International Tour, having landed in Cairo after a long trip started in Rome. The objectives of this first meeting in Cairo and that will proceed on to Damascus, Tripoli and Algiers is the consolidation of the popular movement in the Middle East and in North Africa. In Cairo Secchia has met with President Gamal abd el-Nasser, the indiscussed leader of the Arab world and has been discussing closer ties and trade with Italy. While Nasser is surely the most important player in the region, the visit to Algiers scheduled for the next week holds even more importance. Secchia has long been a supporter of the algerian struggle for independence and has found their long battle close to the battle he had fought himself during the War of National Liberation. After having met the various Heads of State and Government, Secchia is also scheduled to take part in the congresses of many local Communist parties and discuss with their leaders a common strategy of development in the region.

The next stop of Secchia's International Tour comes in a very tense situation and region. The General Secretary is once again visiting the Middle East but this time he is visiting the counties victims of Israeli aggression. A new round of talks with President Nasser has already been scheduled and now the Chairman is busy in a meeting with George Habbash and Yasser Arafat, two of the most important representatives of the Palestinian people. In these round of talks Secchia is bringing forwards all his solidarity and offering financial support to the victims of the attack, besides offering also the possibility of military cooperation with the involved countries. The crimes of Israel shall hardly be forgotten by the Arab people and the Italian government sends all the support it can.

Finally the last stop of Secchia's International Tour has come. The General Secretary is this time visiting the Horn of Africa to strengthen relations with the newly established revolutionary juntas in the region and express all of his hopes on the young revolutions of Africa. Currently he is residing in Addis Ababa and Italo-Ethiopian relations seem to be positive for the first time in a century, the issue of reparations has already come up but Secchia promised nothing. Instead he has been actively participating in the local intellectual scene, attending various conferences and meeting the young ethiopians leading the country our of feudalism. In the next week Secchia is expected to fly to Sudan to attend the Congress of the Sudanese Communist Party who has had a growing and decisive role in the country politics.

The Government of Mao in China has recently launched what it has called the "Great Proletarian Cultural Revolution", a society-wide effort to tackle the issues of class struggle under socialism and the abolition of remaining reactionary elements within chinese society. The revolutionary impetus has had great impact on the whole world and now our party is considering if it is the case to launch a minor campaign that takes inspiration from the chinese events. The supporters of this so called "Cultural and anti-Fascist Revolution" argue that we may learn from the chinese a new structure of rankless military, more fluid and adaptable, while also arguing that there is a need to purge the remnants of the fascist ventennium from Italian society. Indeed the former fascists within the government and its institutions are a lot and some of those keep espousing their reactionary rethoric, the issue of the church is also another big point that such a campaign could address. Attacking the Church and its anti-Communist propaganda could finally give us more control in the southern regions where priests are keeping society hostage.

General Secretary Secchia has unfortunately died at the age of 72 due to health reasons. Now the party has assembled to decide the fate of the country. While Pietro Ingrao, a reformist on the left very active in the cooperative movement, that has managed to rise the ranks thanks to the cultural revolution, has temporarily been acting as General Secretary, his rule is all but decided, a gang of four has formed to contrast his rise. This group of hardliners is headed by Arrigo Boldrini, a former partisan leader who has been very close to Secchia throughout all the steps of his carreer, ostensibly the most moderate of the 4. To help his rise Boldrini has allied with Secchia's old associate Giuseppe Alberganti, the revolutionary anti-revisionist calabrese trade union leader Enzo Misefari and the Italian ambassador to Beijing Osvaldo Pesce. The battle is on, we shall see who comes on top.

The election of Luigi Longo to the position of General Secretary has lead to a wave of normalization with the USSR. Longo's pragmatism and his ability to mediate conflicts brought him to a round of talks with soviet leadership over the re-unification of the communist movement. Longo has flown to Moscow where he has been discussing the terms of such a normalization. Longo's goal is to gain for Italy an independent position that would permit the country to express constructive criticisms and manage an own foreign policy, but shall the soviets be picky we may not have much chance and bow to their line.

Tensions and ideological differences between Italian and Soviet Governments have reached a boiling point after Kurshchev's enounciation of Peaceful Coexistance. Our delegation seems to have alligned during the latest international conferences with the chinese ones and it is rumoured that Mao himself is seeking our for Secchia to build together an alternative communist front. The chinese have always been great allies and such an alliance could very much benefit us, but the isolation that could come from this could be bigger than any benefit so we should very much also take into consideration the eventuality of a neutral future for Italy, independent of Mao and Kurshchev.

The agricultural policies of comrade Togliatti have long been acknowledged as a failure, and now that Longo is General Secretary that issue can finally be addressed. Coming from a farmer's family himself and being very popular with the countryside, Longo has planned through and for an extensive reform of the national's primary sector. The main body of this reform is going to be the Legacoop, thanks to the organizing body, that will itself undergo a structural change to give more power to its local branches, the collective farms are going to be subject to less state control and instead allow to run their own businesses. Legacoop will secure better prices for specific crops while taxes will be lowered. New farming tools are also being deployed and will be turned to the cooperatives. Lastly, through the Legacoops collective farms will now be able to group themselves independently on a regional basis to better compete on the local and international market.

Thanks to the works of the Institute for Communist Studies a never seen before testament of late leader Togliatti has been found among his manuscripts. The text was found during the composition of Togliatti's Collected Works. This discovery set new light on the thought of the father of the Republic, who appears to have taken a much harsher stance on the USSR during the last days of his life. According to the manuscripts the Hegemonic role of the CPSU over the International Communist Movement has greatly sabotaged the worker's movement and Soviet Socialism itself seems to have taken a blow by this sabotage, having recessed into bureaucratism and authoritarianism. Now great questions arise, shall we publish the full text with the risk of angering our allies, shall we publish a censored version of the text omitting the most outrageous claims or should we just keep the text tacit and pretend it never got discovered?

General Secretary Longo has recently left for Prague to visit the newly elected Chairman of the Czechoslovak Communist Party Alexander Dubcek. Longo has identified in Dubcek a possible ally for his polycentric vision of socialism and wishes to learn more about the project and policies of the reformist leader. Dubcek's "Socialism with a Human Face"  and his gradualist approach to the development of socialism seem to fit very well with the material conditions of Italy and Longo may wish to import some of his visions here, who knows if when he gets back to Rome he shall embark on a new path?

Warsaw Pact troops lead by the USSR have entered Prague in what is officially called "Operation Danube". The military operation comes after weeks of tensions between the USSR and Czechoslovakia over the independent foreign and domestic policies of the latter. Soviet diplomats are asking for our army to also take part in the operation but General Secretary Longo might have differing opinions. Longo has very good relations with the Czechoslovak leader and is somewhat sympathetic to him even on an ideological level, it is not unsurpising if he will decide to defy Moscow's directions and make a public attack on the Invasion.

The Government of the Italian People's Republic headed by Luigi Longo has publically condemned our intervention in Czechoslovakia. This is a dangerous precedent that has already strained our relations with the italians and could do even more danger, but it is true that our intervention in another country at this very moment could only possibly make the situation worse, but this hasn't stopped the KGB's highest ranks from pushing forward the possibility of a palace coup headed by more friendly elements.

Under the guidances of Moscow and help from the KGB conservative Armando Cossutta has immobilized the government moving against General Secretary Longo. Our protests to the Soviet invasion of Czechoslovakia have had an echo and this is the russian answer. Cossutta and other partymen have locked Longo prisoner during a special meeting, in which his leadership is now being decided upon, but there is only a little ammount of time for which the pro-Moscow plotters can keep the session open before the arrival of friendly forces to the General Secretary. Will Italy face the same treatment as Czechoslovakia, or will Longo manage to fend off this coup attempt?

Due to his failing health and the stress faced in the last years of government General Secretary Longo has decided to resign from his position. Longo had a stroke in 1969 and the confrontation with the USSR put the 70 years old leader and too much stress. The Party is now meeting to elect its new general secretary. The most favored successor is Enrico Berlinguer, the former chairman of the FGCI (Italian Communist Youth Federation) and close aide of both Longo and Togliatti. Berlinguer represents a new generation of communists having been born after the Livorno Congress and his policies are set to follow the road traced by the two former leaders, incentivizing the polycentrism of italian communism. On the other side we have Giorgio Napolitano, supported by the Amendola faction, he is considered a reformist and the generational leader of his faction. Napolitano was also born after Livorno but his political path is going to focus more on a European re-approachment and independence from Moscow rather than polycentrism per-se.

Having reached 80 General Secretary Longo has passed away in his sleep. Now the party has called on a special meeting to elect a new secretary. The sectarian struggle within the younger generations of the PCI has reached boiling points and it seems like the most likely candidate is going to be the 70 years old Gian Carlo Pajetta. Pajetta has long been one of the most popular figures within the party and his rule is seen as a possible compromise to safeguard unity of the state. The reformist faction headed by Giorgio Napolitano has widely been calling for distance from the USSR and their ties to the Legacoop establishment has created quite some problems in Emilia-Romagna and Campania, where funds seem to have been embezzled, while the muscovite faction rallied around Armando Cossutta has been waging a real war on Napolitano's reformists. The party is in a very precarious state and we wish they may pick the best choice after all.

The agricultural policies of comrade Togliatti have long been acknowledged as a failure, and now that Amendola is General Secretary that issue can finally be addressed. The General Secretary has long established himself close to the leadership of the Legacoop and wishes to use his position to solve the agricultural issue. Amendola's plan is to break up the old collectivization and instead organize farmers into specialized branches directly through the Legacoop. Each farmer will tie itself to the cooperatives and form independently their agricultural enterprises within the actual system, through the introduction of special bonds they will also be able to get preferential prices.

It is no secret that Amendola's eyes have always been pointed towards Europe and his last proposal makes it even more obvious. After his meeting with the Communist Party of Spain in exile, where he welcomed both the old president Dolores Ibarruri and the younger Chairman Santiago Carrillo, the General Secretary thought we may need a Commission for European Integration tasked to organize and manage a coherent and united worker's movement in the West. The first issues this project faces is the most likely opposition from Moscow of any similiar programme, an independent foreign policy in Europe will seem like a threat to their hegemony and our own financing of europeanist parties might seem like a direct competition to their influence. But the Communist Parties of Western Europe have long actually stood for this position and by giving them a valid platform and backing those sentiments that have had to be silenced until now could finally see their full power unleashed.

Held in Berlin, at the Interhotel Stadt Berlin, after months of delay, the Conference of Communist and Workers Parties of Europe, will sign a turn in the world communist movement. The Soviet CPSU had been pushing for years for the meeting to help strengthen the movement and their position in the world but they don't know what's coming. What was meant to be a reconciliation meeting will begin with the coordinated announcement of General Secretary Amendola and other sympathizers of a New Course for socialism in Europe, Eurocommunism, a new formulation of marxism studied by our and the spanish and french ideological departments that take into account the material conditions of Western Europe and of the new emerging reality. During pre-Conference talks Finland's SKP, Sweden's VPK, San Marino's PCS and Great Britain's CPGB expressed sympathy for our position and possible support in the eventuality of a showdown with the CPSU, while ruling SKJ and PCR, respectively from Socialist Yugoslavia and Romania, also expressed sentiments of animosity towards the Soviets. The work of years will finally have its fruits and we hope the Soviets will not react too harshly to this take of position.

The Italian delegation at the Conerence of Communist and Workers Parties of Europe in Berlin opened the meeting with a harsh attack on our party and way of life. PCI's General Secretary Giorgio Amendola spoke of a "new development in marxism" and reiterated the independence of Italy and other countries from the Soviet Union. Alongside PCF's Georges Marchais and PCE's Santiago Carrillo he also introduced a new prospective of European Socialism that will take its form under the ideological hegemony of Italy. This is untolerable and our agents are already on the move on how to contrast this, some propose a full out military operation while other sectors in the KGB are thinking of a palace coup.

Under the guidances of Moscow and help from the KGB conservative Armando Cossutta has immobilized the government moving against General Secretary Amendola. Our actions and words at the Berlin Conference have had an echo and this is the russian answer. Cossutta and other partymen have locked Amendola prisoner during a special meeting, in which his leadership is now being decided upon, but there is only a little ammount of time for which the pro-Moscow plotters can keep the session open before the arrival of friendly forces to the General Secretary. Will Eurocommunism survive this?.

The Red Army has restored control over the country and the counter-revolutionary forces loyal to Amendola have been defeated. The former General Secretary was arrested and a new Central Committee has been formed. In today's meeting the new direction of the Party elected Armando Cossutta General Secretary and a new era for Italy is born to be made. Society will see a normalization now after the excesses of the Eurocommunist period and our relations with the USSR will go back to normal.

The inability of General Secretary Amendola to maintain his promises and go through with the separation from the USSR and enact the needed reform have lead a group of dissatisfied party members to head a coup against the leader. These young turks who want to go through with the reforms have quickly found a majority within the Plenum of the CC of the PCI and its directive leadership. Alessandro Natta was temporarily elected General Secretary while Enrico Berlinguer will from now on be Prime Minister while Achille Occhetto President of the Parliament. This triumvirate through its collective leadership will surely be able to address all the shortcomings of the previous administration.

The collective leadership has recently fallen apart as Berlinguer with the help of Natta moved towards the removal of Occhetto as President of the Parliament in favour of Pietro Folena, a close associate of Berlinguer. Berlinguer wishes to use this situation to secure an allied government that will be able to elect him General Secretary at the next party congress, but Occhetto is not alone, his position within the party is secured by his ties to the Legacoop and this could very much help in these conditions, outmaneuvering the Prime Minister and his stooges.

Under General Secretary Amendola italian society has vastly liberalized allowing for more expression and creativity. Italian Cinema has become popular worldwide and many literary masterpieces have also been produced but the biggest shocks have been witnessed among the youth. Western counterculture movement have popped up in our peninsula, in Milan, Rome and even Turin, these youngsters have not become rare sights. And as the administration relaxed laws also relaxed, in the last few years various emendments have passed cementifying these democratic gains and securing a safe future for the italians of tomorrow.

At the ripe age of 73 General Secretary Giorgio Amendola died due to an illness in a hospital, a few hours later his wife Germaine Lecocq also died. Having lead the PCI into a more prosperous age and having been a key leader of the Resistance as the PCI's representative to the CLN in 1944 he will surely be remembered by the masses with love. Now the Party has gathered to elect a new leader and the most likely option seems to be Giorgio Napolitano, the long time personal secretary of Amendola and his political heir, but Armando Cossutta and his hardline pro-Soviet faction have been quite combattive and the muscovites seem to be ready to ally with the center to elect Gian Carlo Pajetta, one of the oldest functionaires of the PCI who has always enjoyed much popular support, to avoid the victory of Napolitano's Miglioristi.

The agricultural policies of comrade Togliatti have long been acknowledged as a failure, and now that Ingrao is General Secretary that issue can finally be addressed. The General Secretary believes that to tackle the agricultural problem we must link the farms to the industries. Through the use of the Legacoop cooperatives formed by both industrial and agricultural workers will be formed, with farms providing the factories with food and factories providing new tools for the farms. To these new economic entities it will be granted a degree of autonomy and self-management and they will have to report to the regional branch of Legacoop their monthly productivity.

Following the Hungarian example General Secretary Pietro Ingrao has drafted a revolutionary reform for the Italian economy. The Little New Economic Mechanism as they call it will greatly alter the structure of our economy, shifting to a more decentralized model. Central planning will mosty be abandoned in favour of local planning and local factories will from now on be able to freely associate themselves and form firms selling their labour at the prices they wanted within a state-mediated minimum and maximum. These new economic entity will have full decisional autonomy thanks to the establishment of worker's boards in their management and their control over the firms. These entities will also be able to sell their products abroad or import materials within their economic limits. We hope this will bring us to socialism and make the nation a shining example of a worker's state.

After a year from the draft of the NEM now it is finally the time it gets officially activated. Planners all over the country have been informed and special representatives have been travelling factory by factory for the last year informing workers about what they will be able to do and how to act since this very day. We await the start of operations with big enthusiasm and General Secretary Ingrao is even set to visit some of the newly established businesses in the next few hours to talk with workers and make a great propaganda image for the medias.

A conservative shift in Moscow has brought the Little NEM under suspicious and many wonder if it's the case to continue the reform at all. The general consensus is to tone it down for the time being while not touching its fundamental basis, maintaining worker's control of the firms but masking it for a couple of years, even though many do not wish to give Moscow even an inch and would like to procede in defiance with their wishes like nothing happened. As the recent events in the Warsaw Pact have shown we have to be careful to not anger the russian bear and face the destruction of the long awaited reforms.

I the last few year the Italian People's Republic lead by General Secretary Pietro Ingrao has undergone what they have called the "Little New Economic Mechanism", a society-wide reform to bring worker's closer to the control of the industries and have a more efficient and streamlined economy. These reforms have greatly impacted our influence in the country and Italy has surpassed economically many other brotherly states. Some wonder if they should just let off like this even when we advised to not undergo such changes or if they are in need of a regime change from the inside.

Under the guidances of Moscow and help from the KGB conservative Armando Cossutta has immobilized the government moving against General Secretary Ingrao. Our defiance of Moscow's order has incited a strong answer from Moscow and this is it. Cossutta and other partymen have locked Ingrao prisoner during a special meeting, in which his leadership is now being decided upon, but there is only a little ammount of time for which the pro-Moscow plotters can keep the session open before the arrival of friendly forces to the General Secretary. Will the NEM survive?.

Winds of change in Moscow have lead to the Little NEM to be once again favored. Now our broad program of reform can finally be enacted once again in its full extent and our moves of public propaganda in favour of it can be shown with less of a threat. Onwards to worker's power! Onwards to Socialism!.

Political immobilism has characterized the last few years of the Ingrao leadership and general consensus among the Central Committee of the PCI has decided that this situation cannot last. At the latest party meeting a group of concerned functionaires moved against the chairmanship of Ingrao and with a full majority Gian Carlo Pajetta, one of the oldest members of the party, has been elected to oversee a collective leadership of the country. Pajetta has always been a very popular politician among our ranks, having been a party member for more than 40 years and a close collaborator of Togliatti, and he will make a good mediator between the warring factions of the collective leadership.

To strengthen the ideological rigour of our army and of young conscripts General Secretary Ingrao has thought it could be useful to undergo a military reform introducing political commissars in the army on the Soviet and Chinese model. This move is probably going to be only the first of a series of reforms aimed at plasmating the cultural life of the country towards that of a socialist society and it may be very important in the future for the growth of the italians of tomorrow.

As a part of his broader cultural rectification movement General Secretary Ingrao has decided that his next target is going to be the church. Although having been a socialist state for more than 30 years our country still faces the issue of large church influence on the lower strata of the population and we may want to tackle this problem. The campaign is not going to be too harsh but priests will face harsher controls by authorities and the public role of religion is going to be discouraged through awareness programs and public events in favour of atheism.

Having been in power for more than a decade General Secretary Ingrao has come to believe that the country may need a new constitution. The new constitution, the second of the country's history, has already been informally dubbed the "Ingrao Constitution" and aims at cementing the conquests of the last few years of adminisration. The new piece of paper will expand the role of worker's power and worker's democracy in the constitutional framework and civil liberties are also going to see a smaller expansion while the role of the party remains monolithic.

The prosperity brought by the NEM has lead Italy to become an incredibly popular attraction among tourists from the East and the West alike. Due to the rapid increase in tourism based revenue Italy has been dubbed the "Eastern Bloc Beach" and we couldn't be more proud of such a nickname. We succesfully challenged the capitalist notion of socialism as a dull reality with no fun and instead brought them socialist resorts and beaches where everyone can enjoy the sun and have fun, from the poorest to the richest. Our success does not only come from the influxes from abroad but our own citizens have begun to visit the state-owned resorts always more often.

As the General Secretary gets older he begins to look for possible successors and aides and recently a group of Young Mavericks has made itself very prominent in party politics. These Young Miglioristi as they have been called, are a heterogenous group of reformers spearheaded by Achille Occhetto, himself 53, but the real souls of this movements are Walter Veltroni and Massimo D'Alema, both barely 40. Ingrao believes that the rise of these reformers could be encouraged to secure a linear succession and a safe future for Italy, although it will require what is obvious favoritism and corruption.

The Question of the Young Miglioristi has brought upon the anger of Armando Cossutta, longtime leader of the hardliners. A personal meeting between Cossutta and Ingrao has been scheduled for today and the cold reaction of the leader to the project of these mavericks might create common ground for an axis at the next congress to rule the country in a more internationalist way. Shall the two agree on most issues Cossutta would effectively be able to become the number two in the country despite his relative age.

While the Young Miglioristi have managed to find themselves in a very suitable position, they still face the opposition of the hardliner faction headed by Armando Cossutta. Animosity between the two faction have always been present but this situation has been getting Cossutta very aggressive and some even wonder if it's the case to remove him and his followers from the Central Committee and the institutions to avoid any possible unfortunate event.

Having concentrated much power in their hands now the Young Miglioristi have moved against the General Secretary asking him to appoint one of their leader as Prime Minister and as his deputy. Although dismissing the whole government is not impossible it would be a very hard task to do so without any repercussion. Now we have to choose if to fall into the reformists' demands and continue as what is basically a puppet leader or maintain our position clear and dismiss any attempt at a coup.

After the dismissal of the Young Miglioristi, they and their followers have gathered in front of the Botteghe Oscure (The Headquarter of the PCI) protesting their removal from power and wishing for a forceful reinstatement. While masses have gathered right in front of the symbol of power of this country Veltroni and D'Alema have been moving from within threatening the party establishment, force may be needed to disperse such an attempt of power and the tragic story of the Young Miglioristi might end with some blood and an internal purge. If we are not able to maintain a tough line their demands may increase until we are forced to capitulate. Indeed the requests of the reformers have lately been going well further to mere liberalization but they have been calling for privatization and they may start soon begin to question the very role of the party.

The infamous Gang of Four has as expected made her move against General Secretary Ingrao. With the help of the Army they have moved a no-confidence vote against the newly elected leader and wish to be able to swing the Central Committee through the seizing of key facilities. This is a very dangerous situation and we cannot let these fanatics turn the country apart for their own personal gains, we should move the forces loyal to us to their arrest.

Surpisingly the arrest of the Gang of Four has sparked outrage in the masses, who seem to see in them the legacy of Chairman Secchia and a genuine popular movement. Movements in favour of their release have formed in all major cities of the peninsula and in Rome, where they are kept, the situation seems to be escalating very fast, with the threat of a possible break into the prison. We have to lay our orders for the worst case sceanario and decide if in the case of break our police force may or may not be authorized to shoot at evading suspects, even though we hope it shall not come to that.

Having been freed by the riotting masses the Gang of Four has been able to easily seize power regrouping with the army and striking Ingrao in his own home. Their rule is set to mark a radical shift in the politics of the country to a return of the most radical periods of the Secchia leadership. Arrigo Boldrini, Giuseppe Alberganti, Osvaldo Pesce and Enzo Misefari have decided that for the time being the country will be ruled by a collective leadership of the Central Committee of the PCI and during their speech to the nation, after having claimed victory, they have proclaimed themselves the rightful successors of Secchia and of his thought..

Now that Ingrao's leadership has been secured the problem of the USSR has resurfaced. The newly elected leader is much more open to international cooperation with all socialist nations and has proved himself also more pragmatic in many fields. The government has now met to discuss a possible delegation to Moscow and the re-approchment of the Split. Shall we decide to re-open relations with the USSR we will also be able to strike better deal for prime resources that we have been lacking since the early 60's.
